awd_titl_txt: STEM Participation through Community Air Quality Sensor Networks and Data Science
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).
 
Socioeconomic inequities due to climate variation and environmental disparities are amplified in marginalized communities, especially through poor air quality. The air we breathe – a universal variable that connects us all – is a prime determinant of human health and mortality. Long-term exposure to poor air quality, especially particulate matter (PM), is linked to many comorbidities that have been associated with poor health prognoses (e.g., cancer, cardiovascular disease, lung disease), which contribute to approximately 7 million deaths per year. This project will implement face-to-face/virtual community interventions to engage participants in utilizing high- and low-cost air quality sensor technologies together with data analytics to better understand how poor air quality contributes to adverse health impacts, especially COVID-19. 

The project team will work with urban academic institutions and residences in New York City and New Jersey to train them on how to build and operate high- and low-cost air quality sensors for the collection of indoor air quality measurements of PM10, PM2.5, and PM1. The project team will work with community participants to train them how to construct data visualization products to quantify the contribution of air quality levels to adverse health impacts at the individual and county level. This initiative will also engage community participants, such that they are able to quantify the correlation among collected data using well-established statistical approaches. The project team will train participants to utilize open-source tools to examine the physics of where air parcels come from  and forecast where they are going. Lastly, the initiative will implement soft- and hard-skills training and STEM professional development (PD) workshops – all aimed at optimizing recruitment, retention, and successful matriculation in STEM disciplines and careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
Over the course of the last year September 2022 to August 2023 an additional 60 individuals ( homeowners, students, and community professionals) were trained on how to use the Purple Air sensors that were deployed in their homes.This increased our footprint in communities throughout northern and southern Brooklyn, the Bronx and some parts of Queens, NY. In addition, we partnered with two local high schools in Central Brooklyn and their teachers as a way of not only creating awarenss, but to also allow for the students to participate in the community research partnership. Through this process, it provided an opportunity for these individuals to monitor the Air Quality Index for the criterior pollutant Particulate Matter (PM 2.5) in real time using the Purple Air Real-Time air quality map. By being able to assess the changing conditions in their homes through various activities, individuals had a lot of questions when we had our bi-weekly discussions to update on any new observations noted. 

Some of the outcomes noted:

* Increased partnership and collaboration with local schools

*Helped Community members to gain a better understanding on the relationships with indoor activities such as cooking and showering and the release of PM 2.5

*Project served as a guide to help individuals who are upper respiratory suffers

*Students gained opportunities to participate in summer internship programs after being involved with the indoor air quality monitiring with the Purple air Sensors

*Conducted professional development workshops at local high schools

*Increased interest of students wanting to pursue degrees in Environmental Science, switching majors, or choosing to minor in Environmental Science as a result of being involved with this indoor monitoring program 

*Developed an Air Quality Daily Health Check where participants identified with any health symptoms such as nose, throat, eye irritation, shortness of breadth, and sneezing issues at the time of the day when PM was at its' maximum in their household

 


Last Modified: 09/16/2023
Modified by: Dereck Skeete
